text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single large framed image filling the page, no text block interaction; minor inscriptions (labels) at top and near figures but no continuous text; even margins left mostly blank beneath illustration.

color_scheme.color_usage: Red reserved for the garments of divine and prophetic figures (Daniel and the angel), yellow for architecture and soldiers’ mantles, blue-gray used solely in the heavenly background behind the seated deity. Flat application with minimal shading; color choices reinforce hierarchy—divine figures in richer hues, mortals in muted yellow and red. Original pigments remain stable, with slight fading of red vermilion.

features: God in upper register larger and placed above all
Daniel seated at left mid-level reading scroll
Central oversized angel dominates middle space
Group of soldiers at base drawn significantly smaller
Building at right scaled to situate action contextually

decorative_elements: Simple red frame border around scene

drawing_technique.line_style: Fine quill-pen outlines in brown-black ink with consistent weight, minimal internal double-lining
drawing_technique.shading_method: Flat color fields without hatch or wash, no gradation or tonal modeling
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling governs spatial relations; no attempt at linear perspective; overlapping only to indicate foreground placement

content_theme.scene_description: The scene depicts the Angel of the Lord delivering the prophet Daniel from the lions’ den. At upper left, God the Father appears in a rectangular cloud-band against a blue-gray sky, holding a cross-staff and haloed. Below Him at center left, Daniel sits on a simple bench, haloed, reading from a long parchment scroll inscribed with dense script. The central figure is a large winged angel, clad in a red tunic over a gray robe, its right hand raised in blessing or command, its left hand resting on the drapery. To the right stands a small classical temple-like structure representing the den, rendered in lead-tin yellow with a tiled roof and four columned portico. At the base of the image is a row of five soldiers in tunics and mantles of yellow, red, and gray, each holding a long spear, their feet turned slightly outward. The throne of Daniel, the angel’s gesture, and the attentive posture of the soldiers emphasize divine protection. The figures are arranged in three horizontal registers, scaled to indicate importance, with the angel physically larger than the mortal guards.

architectural: Classical temple-style den with tiled roof and columns

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum, smooth and evenly prepared with visible hair-follicle pattern faintly under UV; folio arises from regular quaternion gathering with ruled layout lines.
technical_features.preservation_condition: Overall good; pigments well-preserved with minor flaking of red vermilion at edges; vellum slightly cockled in corners; faint later marginal staining.
notable_physical_characteristics: Visible ruling in plummet beneath illustration
Flat gesso prep beneath color layers for uniform surface
Consistent quill-pen line work with no corrections

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This richly illustrated page from a twelfth-century biblical codex presents a vividly hierarchical composition characteristic of Romanesque manuscript illumination in a monastic scriptorium. The depiction of Daniel’s divine rescue reflects the theological emphasis on angelic mediation prevalent in continental scriptoria of the period. The crisp brown−black outlines, flat color application, and limited palette—vermilion red, lead-tin yellow, and azurite blue-gray—demonstrate both technical economy and symbolic restraint. The collaborative nature of the workshop is evident in the uniformity of line work yet slight variations in figural proportions. The classical temple-like den suggests an awareness of architectural forms, while the hierarchical scaling of God, angel, and soldiers underscores spiritual order. The absence of elaborate marginalia and the use of minimal border decoration indicate this was a functional liturgical Bible, intended for recitation and reflection rather than luxury display. Comparatively, the style aligns with illuminated Bibles produced in north-eastern France during the reign of Henry II, sharing affinities with the Bury Bible’s firm outlines and Abstracted patterning. The page bridges traditional iconography with emerging narrative clarity, anticipating the more naturalistic treatments of the Gothic era while retaining the Romanesque emphasis on symbolic hierarchy.
